Alhajilbrahim Dasuki, the Sul- tan of Sokoto, the man whose ascension to the throne brought so much furore, squabbles, street fights and much bloodshed on the streets of Sokoto, reportedly has put the blame for Chief MKO Ablola's incarceration on Nige- rianjournalists He was quoted to have said these 'pushers' of pen put Ablola in detention. Perhaps, Abiola is on his way out of General Sani Abacha's detention camp and the sultan, whose ascen- sion to the Sultanate stool benefitted immensely from Abiola unguarded loyalty to his friends and his readi- ness to assist them in realising their life ambition, may be preparing the ground so that if Abiola's is eventu- ally out, the Sultan can be counted among those who, unlike those en- dangered specie - journalists - have always stood for Abiola's freedom or even, the realisation of the man- date. But even then, let us show some understanding to the Dasukis and the Abachas. For those who are the architects of the woes that have become our lot as a people in the past two decades, Nemesis is just around the corner and we should understand the hurry to re-write our history, find hapless scapegoats just so that they can have some sleep. Pity, fathers who loan their beg- garly crowns and turbans from the bloody palms of desperate army chief- tains cannot be expected to provide direction to a people in search of authentic heroes. And like I told junior on this score, it is now left to us to guard our loins and begin to write the history of this struggle because it is our struggle. We should do it not in the official gazettes of the architects of our fall from grace to grass, but in the minds, the minds of our children - the real casualties of this season of langst. Mosle m countries rocked by fundamentalist violence in 1994 have identified the grow- ing surge ofextremism as the most directthreat to theirsta- bility next year. Thousands of people have died in mili- tantcampaigns in Algeria and Egypt this year, while Gulf Arab states have taken un- precedented measures to crush simmering fundamen- talist unrest at home. And prospects lookbleak for 1995 with a social and economic crisis threatening the Mos- lem world and providing fer- tile ground for extremist groups looking to increase their support. Mosle m countries rocked by fundamentalist violence in 1994 have identified the grow- ing surge ofextremism as the most directthreat to theirsta- bility next year. Thousands of people have died in mili- tantcampaigns in Algeria and Egypt this year, while Gulf Arab states have taken un- precedented measures to crush simmering fundamen- talist unrest at home. And prospects lookbleak for 1995 with a social and economic crisis threatening the Mos- lem world and providing fer- tile ground for extremist groups looking to increase their support.

For the first time in its history the Organisation of Islamic Con- ference [OIC] adopted a 'code of conduct' in December to face up to the fundamentalist threat. The code, adopted at the OIC summit meeting in Mo- rocco, called on the organisation's 51 members not to finance or support "terrorist acts" and to ensure their terri- tory is not used by violent groups to plan or carry out operations. Intellectuals are also a prime tar- get of Islamic militants in troubled Algeria, where the year drew to a close without any sign of a solu- tion to its its two-year conflict. Violence erupted in February, 1992 when the government cancelled elections which Islamic funda- mentalists were set to win and imposed a state of emergency. Seventeen journalists and dozens of judges, teachers and artists were murdered in 1994, along with 40 tourists.
